content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice job.  Thank you for your patience as we ironed out the details.
Pretty cool
:white_check_mark: Approved the contribution.

Minimum grammar fixes:

1) Here are the 4 rules of killer sudoku.  (You are missing the word "are".)

2) The cages are represented in a 9x9 grid with and identifier (the word "and" should be "an").

3) Same sentence as #2 above - the word "follow" should be changed to "follows".

Rule number 4 is difficult to make grammatically correct with the nesting of possession - a cage has cells, the cells have values, the values have a sum.  I really don't know the proper way to fix that grammar and make the chain of possession clear.

Because I find rule #4 difficult to correct, I am choosing to repost my original suggestions for the goal section from 18 days ago:

You may know the sudoku puzzle. Killer sudoku adds a new rule with cages. A cage is a group of cells, the sum of which must equal the cage value. Numbers cannot repeat within cages.

Here are the 4 rules of killer sudoku:
1. Each row must have numbers from 1 to 9 with no repetition
2. Each column must have numbers from 1 to 9 with no repetition
3. Each region (3x3 square) must have numbers from 1 to 9 with no repetition
4. Each cage's cell numbers must sum to the cage value, with no repetition among numbers

In the Input section: I don't think "repartition" is the word you are looking for.  I believe repartition is a verb meaning to partition something again or a noun meaning a second or additional dividing or distribution.  Using the words "cage partitions"  is probably what you are looking for.

I need to think about the Input section.  It is difficult to read.

Why mention "You can have the same number in the cage." when NONE of the expected solutions to all the test cases and validators exhibits such a feature?

I agree with Timinator's comment below. Please remove that sentence from the statement. Thanks.
Good Puzzle.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks great

It's a nice puzzle.
I would include some grammar fixes or small rephrasing:
- "[...] puzzle, Killer Sudoku add a new rule [...]" => "puzzle; Killer Sudoku adds a new rule"
- "[...] group of cells which the sum their values must equal the value [...]" => "group of cells summing up to the value"
- "Each rows should [...]" => "Rows should ..." or "Each row should ..."
- "Each columns should [...]" => same
-  "Each cages cells [...]" => same, or "Cage cells sum up to..."
- "9 first characters [...]" => "First 9 characters"
- "[...] character, 9 last characters [...]" => "character. Last 9 characters"

Please ignore first bullets if you're rephrasing the cage part some other way.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: seems to be okay

the definition of a cage is difficult to understand in the first part

Here is how I would rephrase it:

A cage is a group of cells. each cell an ID representing their cage a-zA-F
The sum of the cells in a cage must equal the value printed in the last line of input

The Expert Validator is the only test case/validator I needed to use recursive backtracking to solve.  In my mind, this makes the Expert Validator significantly harder than the other 7 test cases/validators.  I'd like to see the Expert Test Case be difficult enough to require backtracking.  Grid reduction in Killer Sudoku is very challenging, but I see grid reduction as a less difficult task than recursive backtracking to find a solution.

According to the Wikipedia page about Killer Sudoku, "Numbers cannot repeat within cages".   Here are some suggested changes to your goal statement:

You may know the sudoku puzzle. Killer sudoku adds a new rule with cages. A cage is a group of cells, the sum of which must equal the cage value. Numbers cannot repeat within cages.

Here are the 4 rules of killer sudoku:
1. Each row must have numbers from 1 to 9 with no repetition
2. Each column must have numbers from 1 to 9 with no repetition
3. Each region (3x3 square) must have numbers from 1 to 9 with no repetition
4. Each cage's cell numbers must sum to the cage value, with no repetition among numbers

More to come.  I am working through a solution.

Input section
* Suggest to mention that an empty cell is represented by the {{.}} character.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer" or "write solution").

Cases
* Is the solution always unique? Or would there be multiple solutions and one of them should be chosen based on some criteria?

Thanks.
Thanks for the feedback, I've added those information in the puzzle

Hi Timinator,

Thanks for the comment. 

I generated test cases and  validator from https://sudoku.com/fr/killer and in this game the rule about no repetition in cages is not present. I also didn't used it in my solution, I guess it's better not to add it in this puzzle.

Hi Timinator,

I used a recursive function to solve this puzzle and I see backtracking:
- hard: test case: 362, validator: 765
- Expert: test case: 20134, validator:  3037

I didn't want this puzzle to do too much recursion, the goal is to add the new rules of cages.
Agree. I also found cages difficult to understand at first.
Thank for the feedback, I've fixed those points.

Regarding the Input section:

Please add a semicolon after "First 9 characters", similar to the way you have a semicolon after "Last 9 characters".

For the part about the last 9 characters, I suggest:

Last 9 characters: cage ID for each of the nine cells in this row of the sudoku grid.

Line 10 - you use the word "groups".  Please change this one word to cages.
All very good and valid comments!

Thank a lot Timinator for all your comments.

I think I changed everything you said.

Looks good!
I would also adjust ‚Äú group of cells which the summing up to‚Äù => ‚Äúgroup of cells summing up to‚Äù.
Thanks for the sustained effort üëç

Thanks Alexfr88 and BlueCypher for the feedback.

I've added some more information and a link to the online solution to let people better understand this puzzle.

Hope this will be better.

I ran your code.  It is surprisingly slow on Test Case 4, but crazy fast on Validator 4.  This leads me to believe I am missing something on Validator 4.

I have enjoyed this puzzle tremendously and now I'm fascinated to figure out what I'm missing that makes your algorithm so much faster than mine on Validator 4.

I'm willing to approve without any changes to the test cases/validators under the assumption that I'm missing something on Validator 4.  However, I'd also be thrilled to see you add more test cases and validators.

I had the same issue. I actually don't know how it works without backtracking. I also got big variance when changing brute force from 1..9 to 9..1 (e.g. reduced from 21s to 9ms on an older algo).

Current code passes the expert cases though (although barely): https://gist.github.com/nicolaes/7587483fc434efd0e55cbcdde321a33c

Nice job!  It never occurred to me to just brute force the entire thing no matter what.

Here is some fun data comparing your solution to my solution on ONLY the first 7, which I am able to solve with zero backtracking.  Your time to solve is first.  My time to solve is second.  I'm having each of our algorithms do 20 iterations in the CG IDE and taking an average.  The only exception is #7 where I'm just doing an estimate across multiple submits because your algorithm only solves that problem one time within the time limit..

1 - 0.3ms  vs  2ms
2 - 0.59ms  vs  2ms
3 - 0.88ms  vs 2.5ms
4 - 0.83ms  vs 2.9ms
5 - 57ms  vs  6ms
6 - 111ms  vs  9.5ms
7 - 3,800ms vs 32ms

As the puzzles get harder and harder, it looks like grid reduction becomes critical before doing any backtracking.  I was hoping the test cases would get hard enough to  engage that topic, but your solution proves that all 8 cases can be done within the 5000ms (I think) time limit strictly doing brute force backtracking.

And another interesting comparison.  What if we remove all numbers and change all input grids to:

.........
.........
.........
.........
.........
.........
.........
.........
.........

1 - 300ms  vs  timeout
2 - 3000ms  vs  250ms
3 - 4800ms  vs  60ms
4 - 900ms  vs  37ms
5 - 400ms  vs  36ms
6 - 900ms  vs  2000ms
7 - no change of course since the grid already doesn't have numbers

With all numbers removed from all grids, I am only able to find solutions to #3, #4, #5 and #7 without any backtracking.

I'm playing with Algorithm X for my backtracking and my implementation is not the super fast Dancing Links (DLX) implementation, which I'm guessing is why my algorithm is slow when it needs to use backtracking.

I need to learn what Algorithm X is. But before that, your times look awesome! 
By grid reduction, I assume you mean eliminating possibilities for each cell until correct solution is revealed. Would be great to see some of your code (if you're ok sharing).

You are correct.  For each of the 81 cells, you create a list of possible numbers.  Then through a process of elimination, you reduce those lists of possible numbers as much as you can.  For instance, if a cage has only 2 cells that must add up to 8, then you can eliminate 4 from both lists.  Why?  A cage cannot contain duplicate numbers so you can't have two 4s in the same cage.  You could also say that if your cage only has two cells, those two cells must be in the same row or the same column.  Then, once again, you can eliminate the 4 from each of the two cells' lists of possibilities because you can't have duplicate 4s in a row or column.  After that process is over, you might have a complete grid, but even if you don't, you have significantly reduced how much backtracking you must do.  What I think I need to do is either use your backtracking or switch my Algorithm X backtracking to Dancing Links (DLX).  My grid reduction is obviously helpful.  My backtracking is my slow part.

Here's the bottom line.  I found the process of grid reduction incredibly challenging, and therefore, super fun.  For that reason, I'm not going to share my code.  I don't want to possibly deprive you of that experience.  And, because the author is so fast on Validator 4, I truly believe there might be something else I have missed in terms of grid reduction. Unfortunately, I don't know PHP, so the author's code is a bit overwhelming to me.

I want this puzzle to be approved.  I'm also interested in exploring the idea of another puzzle that we might call Extreme Killer Sudoku where every test case and validator is extreme expert.  I'm wondering if there are Killer Sudoku puzzles that couldn't be solved within the time limit by backtracking alone.

As for Algorithm X, I suggest just starting with:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knuth%27s_Algorithm_X

Then take a look at this and figure out how the author solves basic Sudoku using Algorithm X:

https://www.cs.mcgill.ca/~aassaf9/python/algorithm_x.html

Then, you'll need to learn about Dancing Links.

And, Finally, @5DN1L has compiled this awesome list:

https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/puzzles-solvable-by-dancing-links/196871

I suggest starting with Sudoku Solver (basic AlgorithmX) and then moving on to n-Queens (Algorithm X with the addition of at most 1-time constraints).

Right. Thanks for the directions. 
About sharing the code - I agree. It's more interesting if I write it from scratch. 

If you like the killer sudoku, I'm working for a few months to solve this automatically: https://app.crackingthecryptic.com/sudoku/jMQR24JRBN . There's a video on how is it done manually, but found it difficult putting that in code.

Hi Timinator and blueCypher, I've solved all the test cases and validators here using Algorithm X (without Dancing Links), so it's doable with that approach. And it's not slow at all, e.g. it took just 0.15 second and <0.4 second (running on CG, not offline) for the last pair of initially empty grid cases and with Python.

Those are great times, especially considering you are doing backtracking.  I am converting all input grids to completely empty grids just like test case 4 and validator 4 and I can now solve all test cases and all validators with zero backtracking with all less than 0.5 seconds inside the CG IDE.  All of my times are over 0.3 seconds, most likely because I'm using empty grids as starting points.

I find this to be a really cool optimization exercise.  I'm going to see if test cases can be generated to stump solutions that don't do some sort of optimization and explore what we might be able to do in a follow-on puzzle.

I clicked on the website you referenced and I see this rule:

Chaque cage, ligne, colonne ou bloc de 3x3 cases ne peut pas contenir deux fois le m√™me chiffre.

Google Translate gave me this for a translation:

Each cage, row, column or block of 3x3 squares cannot contain the same number twice.
